ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My ability to read very difficult theory and poetry grew, and I learned how to sit with a piece of literature or art and completely analyze it and deconstruct ideas.
How to closely analyze pieces of literature and discuss / write essays about those pieces.
I learnt how to write a college essay, how to analyze poetry and art and to evaluate the sublime in literature and all spheres of life.
How to write a college-level humanities essay (my skills were rather basic I think).
A better understanding of the sublime and its importance, how to close read philosophical texts
My writing skills and reading skills improved.
I learned a lot about how to think critically and dig deeper into text and art. I also learned more skills to speak eloquently and express my ideas.

We looked at the sublime through various different fields, so I feel like I gained a sense of what collegiate philosophy, literature, and art theory looks like in addition to familiarizing myself with the format of the college essay
How different writers viewed sublimity, what exactly sublimity can be defined as.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very discussion based, so it is important that people participate, but otherwise fantastic.

The readings were consistently stimulating and interesting. The syllabus was a nice overview of the intellectual discourse of the sublime over time, and it was a nice balance between breadth and depth. However, we would only discuss a few sentences of each text (if not less) each seminar, which made the actual classes feel useless. I seldom walked away from class thinking that I had gained a better grasp of the texts or that I had learnt anything substantial. A lot of the time we focused on the authors themselves in relation to broad contexts, instead of the actual content of the readings. Moreover, discussions seemed open at first, but always ended up skewing towards what students thought the professor wanted to hear instead of actually being a space for us to raise different perspectives. The discussion environment could also be better because some students would talk a lot and others not at all.
I think that some of the discussions were hard to follow due to my lack of knowledge in religion. The readings that arent super intertwined with religion were interesting though.

Strengths: lots of discussions, passionate and nice professor
Weaknesses: difficult to pay attention sometimes, essay prompts could be a bit vague

The professor is really passionate and knowledgeable about what he does. The class is very discussion based and he gives everyone an opportunity to speak. The class really changed my perception of a lot of fundamental ideas of what it means to be human, divine, transcend boundaries, and more.

I thought that this course could more efficiently use class time. Usually class was spent simply reading over the assigned readings for the week without much involved discussion. Many students were able to get by without doing any work for the class.

Strengths: discussion section allows for a better understanding of text

Weaknesses: texts can be incredibly difficult to read, not much help deciphering text

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, it is very theory heavy but is so fascinating. I'm interested in stem, but this class was very interesting as well.

Yes. Professor Soles creates a pretty welcoming environment, even when you feel like youre really lost in the topic matter / dont know what to say during class. I think the class expanded my views of a lot of things in life, so I would recommend this course if you have the chance to take it. Professor Soles helps you a lot with learning how to write college essays as well.
Only if you are very very interested in the sublime as a humanities concept. Otherwise there are better first-year seminars and humanities courses out there.
Yes. It is enjoyable, mentally stimulating and pretty chill. Best professor ever.
If you are really interested in philosophy yes, if not no- the class is different than what i imagined from the syllabus

I would recommend this if you have interest in art or academic texts on the sublime. The professor is very engaging and cares a lot about what he does. Challenged me a lot and I feel this is one of the classes where the new ways of thinking will really stick with me.

I would not recommend this course unless the student was very interested in the material at hand. A course on the sublime that failed to establish a working definition was not very effective. Many times it felt that none of the students were engaged.
